content:
Any conviction against the driver for an offence under Section 67 to 71A of the Road Traffic Act (Cap.92.1985 Ed.) and/or any statutory law regarding the abuse of drugs, shall be conclusive evidence for the exception stated at General Exclusion 1(b)(iii) above to apply where the offence was committed at the time of an accident or event giving rise to claim under this Policy.
2. Any liability that You have agreed to take on under an agreement, which You would not otherwise have if the agreement did not exist.
3. Any claim or provide any benefit hereunder to the extent that the provision of such cover, payment of such claim or provision of such benefit would expose Us to any sanction, prohibition or restriction under United Nations resolutions or the trade or economic sanctions, laws or regulations of the European Union or United Kingdom or United States of America.
questions: What does General Exclusion 1(b)(iii) refer to in the context of the Road Traffic Act?
How does a conviction under Section 67 to 71A of the Road Traffic Act affect a claim under the policy?
What are the implications of a driver being convicted for drug abuse at the time of an accident?
What type of liabilities are excluded from coverage if they arise from an agreement?
Under what conditions would a claim not be covered due to an agreement made by the policyholder?
What restrictions might prevent the insurance company from providing cover or paying a claim?
How do United Nations resolutions impact the insurance coverage provided?
What role do sanctions from the European Union, United Kingdom, or United States play in insurance claims?
Can an insurance claim be denied based on international trade or economic sanctions?
What are the consequences of providing insurance benefits that conflict with international sanctions or laws?
